name: SimpleGraph.Subgraph.deleteVerts
docString:
Given a subgraph and a set of vertices, delete all the vertices from the subgraph,
if present. Any edges incident to the deleted vertices are deleted as well.

Given a simple graph and replacing a vertex with another non-equal vertex preserves adjacency for all other vertices.

type:
‚àÄ {V : Type u_1} [inst : DecidableEq V] (G : SimpleGraph V) (s : V) {t w : V},

The theorem `Cardinal.toNat_lift` states that for any cardinal number `c` (from the universe `v`), the process of converting that cardinal to a natural number remains unchanged, whether the cardinal is first lifted to a higher universe (from `v` to `max v u`) or not. In other words, lifting the universe of the cardinal does not affect its conversion to a natural number. This theorem guarantees the compatibility of the cardinal number universe lifting operation with the function that maps cardinals to natural numbers.

type: ‚àÄ (c : Cardinal.{v}), Cardinal.toNat (Cardinal.lift.{u, v} c) = Cardinal.toNat c
name: Cardinal.toNat_lift
docString: The theorem `Cardinal.toNat_lift` states that for any cardinal number `c` (from the universe `v`), the process of converting that cardinal to a natural number remains unchanged, whether the cardinal is first lifted to a higher universe (from `v` to `max v u`) or not. In other words, lifting the universe of the cardinal does not affect its conversion to a natural number. This theorem guarantees the compatibility of the cardinal number universe lifting operation with the function that maps cardinals to natural numbers.

The theorem `Vector.toList_cons` states that for any type `Œ±`, any natural number `n`, any element `a` of type `Œ±`, and any vector `v` of length `n` with elements of type `Œ±`, if you construct a new vector by prepending `a` to `v` and then convert this vector to a list, you get the same result as if you first convert `v` to a list and then prepend `a` to this list. In other words, converting a vector to a list preserves the operation of prepending an element.

type: ‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u} {n : ‚Ñï} (a : Œ±) (v : Vector Œ± n), (a ::·µ• v).toList = a :: v.toList
name: Vector.toList_cons
docString: The theorem `Vector.toList_cons` states that for any type `Œ±`, any natural number `n`, any element `a` of type `Œ±`, and any vector `v` of length `n` with elements of type `Œ±`, if you construct a new vector by prepending `a` to `v` and then convert this vector to a list, you get the same result as if you first convert `v` to a list and then prepend `a` to this list. In other words, converting a vector to a list preserves the operation of prepending an element.

docString: Generate a random natural number in the interval [lo, hi].

Core implementation of `bestFirstSearch`, that works by iteratively updating an internal state,
consisting of a priority queue of `MLList m Œ±`.

At each step we pop an element off the queue,
compute its children (lazily) and put these back on the queue.

type:
{œâ : Type u_1} ‚Üí
  {Œ± : Type} ‚Üí
    (prio : Œ± ‚Üí Thunk œâ) ‚Üí
      (Œµ : Œ± ‚Üí Type) ‚Üí
        [inst : LinearOrder œâ] ‚Üí
          [inst_1 : (a : Œ±) ‚Üí Estimator (prio a) (Œµ a)] ‚Üí
            [I : ‚àÄ (a : Œ±), WellFoundedGT ‚Üë(Set.range (EstimatorData.bound (prio a)))] ‚Üí
              [inst : Ord œâ] ‚Üí
                [inst : Ord Œ±] ‚Üí
                  {m : Type ‚Üí Type} ‚Üí
                    [inst : Monad m] ‚Üí
                      [inst : Alternative m] ‚Üí
                        [inst : (a : Œ±) ‚Üí Bot (Œµ a)] ‚Üí Option ‚Ñï ‚Üí (Œ± ‚Üí MLList m Œ±) ‚Üí Œ± ‚Üí MLList m Œ±
name: impl
docString:
Core implementation of `bestFirstSearch`, that works by iteratively updating an internal state,
consisting of a priority queue of `MLList m Œ±`.

At each step we pop an element off the queue,
compute its children (lazily) and put these back on the queue.

docString:

A single step of the best first search.
Pop an element, and insert its children back into the queue,
with a trivial estimator for their priority.

type:
{œâ : Type u_1} ‚Üí
  {Œ± : Type} ‚Üí
    (prio : Œ± ‚Üí Thunk œâ) ‚Üí
      (Œµ : Œ± ‚Üí Type) ‚Üí
        [inst : LinearOrder œâ] ‚Üí
          [inst_1 : (a : Œ±) ‚Üí Estimator (prio a) (Œµ a)] ‚Üí
            [I : ‚àÄ (a : Œ±), WellFoundedGT ‚Üë(Set.range (EstimatorData.bound (prio a)))] ‚Üí
              [inst_2 : Ord œâ] ‚Üí
                [inst_3 : Ord Œ±] ‚Üí
                  {m : Type ‚Üí Type} ‚Üí
                    [inst_4 : Monad m] ‚Üí
                      [inst_5 : Alternative m] ‚Üí
                        [inst_6 : (a : Œ±) ‚Üí Bot (Œµ a)] ‚Üí
                          (maxSize : Option ‚Ñï) ‚Üí
                            (Œ± ‚Üí MLList m Œ±) ‚Üí
                              BestFirstQueue prio Œµ m Œ± maxSize ‚Üí m (Œ± √ó BestFirstQueue prio Œµ m Œ± maxSize)
name: impl.go
docString:
A single step of the best first search.
Pop an element, and insert its children back into the queue,
with a trivial estimator for their priority.

type: Mathlib.Explode.Entries ‚Üí Lean.Expr ‚Üí Mathlib.Explode.Entry ‚Üí Mathlib.Explode.Entry √ó Mathlib.Explode.Entries

Given an element `x : Œ±` of `l : List Œ±` such that `x ‚àà l`, get the next
element of `l`. This works from head to tail, (including a check for last element)
so it will match on first hit, ignoring later duplicates.

For example:
 * `next [1, 2, 3] 2 _ = 3`
 * `next [1, 2, 3] 3 _ = 1`
 * `next [1, 2, 3, 2, 4] 2 _ = 3`
 * `next [1, 2, 3, 2] 2 _ = 3`
 * `next [1, 1, 2, 3, 2] 1 _ = 1`

type: {Œ± : Type u_1} ‚Üí [inst : DecidableEq Œ±] ‚Üí (l : List Œ±) ‚Üí (x : Œ±) ‚Üí x ‚àà l ‚Üí Œ±
name: List.next
docString:
Given an element `x : Œ±` of `l : List Œ±` such that `x ‚àà l`, get the next
element of `l`. This works from head to tail, (including a check for last element)
so it will match on first hit, ignoring later duplicates.

For example:
 * `next [1, 2, 3] 2 _ = 3`
 * `next [1, 2, 3] 3 _ = 1`
 * `next [1, 2, 3, 2, 4] 2 _ = 3`
 * `next [1, 2, 3, 2] 2 _ = 3`
 * `next [1, 1, 2, 3, 2] 1 _ = 1`

If we dilate a convex set about a point in its interior by a scale `t > 1`, the interior of
the result includes the closure of the original set.

‚àÄ {E : Type u_3} [inst : AddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : Module ‚Ñù E] [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace E]

  Convex ‚Ñù s ‚Üí ‚àÄ {x : E}, x ‚àà interior s ‚Üí ‚àÄ (t : ‚Ñù), 1 < t ‚Üí closure s ‚äÜ interior (‚áë(AffineMap.homothety x t) '' s)
name: Convex.closure_subset_interior_image_homothety_of_one_lt
docString:
If we dilate a convex set about a point in its interior by a scale `t > 1`, the interior of
the result includes the closure of the original set.
